divers . autres produits.description: This sub-item captures the footprint of new product purchases, linked to a person's expenditure and standard of living, via a macro-economic approach. As with the method used for societal services, we use the results of the SDES work to reconstitute the carbon footprint of purchases not captured "elsewhere" in the test for an average French person. Despite significant limitations (to be discussed shortly), this question is relevant for a number of reasons: - To broaden the scope of consumption covered by Nos Gestes Climat: here, we take into account expenses that are not captured in the rest of the test, such as **decoration, plants, etc.** such as **decoration, plants, gardening, kitchen equipment, household linen, materials for creative hobbies, DIY.** These purchases are often used over the long term and should therefore be amortized according to the type of product, but in this approach we consider that the footprint of purchases is equivalent from year to year and that depreciation is not necessary. - Enable us to group our purchases of new products into a single question and avoid focusing on "small items" with too many questions: how many vases? How many books? How many bath mats? How many cutlery sets? etc. - Raising awareness of new product purchases. In Nos Gestes Climat, the footprint of second-hand products is attributed to the original purchaser of the item. Thus, the footprint of a second-hand product is currently considered to be zero (which is clearly stated in the question). We have therefore considered in this question a breakdown of the following items whose carbon content has been assigned among all economic branches / sub-branches: - Horticulture (plants, accessories, delivery) - Glassware, tableware, kitchen utensils - Leather goods, accessories (lighters, umbrellas, sunglasses, etc.), baby equipment - Carpets and other coverings, installation and repair - Home and garden tools - Repair services for computers and personal and household goods - Products for routine home maintenance and repairs - Other manufactured products such as games, toys, sports equipment, musical instruments, jewelry and watches > For example, the "Horticulture" item comprises the "Plant reproduction" sub-branch, representing 2% of the "Agriculture and horticulture products" branch in terms of sales "the "Wholesale of flowers and plants" sub-branch, which accounts for 0.2% of the "Wholesale trade, excluding automobiles and motorcycles per inhabitant" branch, and finally the "Retail trade of flowers, plants, seeds, fertilizers, pets and pet food in specialized stores", representing 1.5% of the "Retail trade, excluding automobiles and motorcycles per capita" branch However, **the footprint captured in this question should be taken with a grain of salt**. Indeed, the macro-economic approach has several limitations, as outlined in our technical guide on societal services, in particular due to the precision of the initial data. The calculation is also based on a single figure, identical for all citizens. Nevertheless, this question proposes a modularization of the footprint via a multi-stake nivy question: Nevertheless, this method of calculation is preferred here to monetary ratios, which have an uncertainty of 80%. The emission factors in the carbon base are not up to date with today's inflation levels, and those averaged for this question are very heterogeneous (we aggregate the factor associated with publishing (books), but also that associated with plastics or metals). To conclude on this subject, and this is undoubtedly the biggest obstacle to the use of monetary ratios, the carbon intensity of a euro spent on a purchase is not at all representative of the product's real footprint. For example, it's not at all obvious that a more expensive book has a bigger footprint. Similarly, a set of linen sheets could very well have a footprint 5 times smaller than a set of cotton sheets lower than a set made from cotton (flax requires very few resources to grow), yet the latter is likely to cost up to 10 times as much.

divers . autres produits . facteur corre.description: This factor is used to modulate the footprint of new product purchases according to INSEE household expenditure statistics by decile.
divers . autres produits . facteur corre.note: For this question, which is subject to a number of uncertainties, both in terms of the "Top Down" calculation method used here, and in terms of the composition of the emission categories making up this question, we have chosen to work on the basis of the INSEE study of household expenditure in 2017 emissions, we have chosen to work on the basis of the INSEE study of household expenditure in 2017 in order to establish a scale of expenditure that will enable us to modulate the footprint associated with this question via orders of magnitude. According to these data (see aggregation table below), the level of expenditure per French person is around ‚Ç¨1,000 per year, **a level of expenditure that varies according to the income decile of the population**. *Note that to obtain the level of expenditure per individual, we divide the average expenditure per household by 2.2, which is the average size of a French household* *In this table, the percentages indicated in columns D1 to D10 are corrective factors associated with the spending deciles in relation to the average spending for each of these sectors* To make it easier to answer the question, we propose 3 spending levels corresponding to deciles D3, D6 and D9 (rounded). | Category | Average expenditure per household | Average expenditure per French person | D1 | D2 | D3 | D4 | D5 | D6 | D7 | D8 | D9 | D10 | |---------------------------------------|----------------------------|------------------------------|-----|-----|-----|-----|-----|------|------|------|------|------| | Games, Jewelry, Leisure | 319 | 145,0 | 55% | 44% | 65% | 50% | 79% | 94% | 92% | 194% | 169% | 158% | | Horticulture | 146 | 66,4 | 51% | 42% | 56% | 64% | 86% | 109% | 105% | 121% | 182% | 182% | | Leather goods and other accessories | 71 | 32.3 | 38% | 55% | 58% | 62% | 56% | 77% | 114% | 156% | 193% | 196% | | Carpets and other coverings | 14 | 6.4 | 7% | 21% | 93% | 71% | 64% | 71% | 157% | 207% | 121% | 164% | | Dishes, kitchenware | 80 | 36.4 | 43% | 55% | 63% | 96% | 71% | 85% | 120% | 173% | 133% | 160% | | Tools (Household and Garden) | 209 | 95.0 | 22% | 54% | 67% | 61% | 69% | 79% | 153% | 135% | 114% | 243% | | Repair Services | 1,121 | 509.5 | 49% | 59% | 70% | 69% | 75% | 94% | 108% | 131% | 146% | 198% | | 176 | 80.0 | 36% | 29% | 48% | 44% | 88% | 181% | 169% | 139% | 91% | 172% | | **Total** | **2,136** | **970.9** | **45%** | **52%** | **66%** | **64%** | **76%** | **100%** | **116%** | **144%** | **145%** | **191%** |

divers . autres produits . niveau de d√©.question: The test doesn't yet capture all your consumption, so how would you estimate your level of spending on new products (home decoration, DIY, games, hobbies, tools, etc.)?
divers . autres produits . niveau de d√©.description:
To keep the interface simple, we propose an estimate, via your expenses, of the footprint of consumer goods
that you don't think you've included in the previous questions.

It concerns: **games, decoration, kitchen equipment, household linen, materials for hobbies and crafts, plants, etc.**

> üí° The orders of magnitude in ‚Ç¨ proposed here are based on INSEE household expenditure statistics. The average French person spends ‚Ç¨80/month on these items.
divers . autres produits . niveau de d√©.note: The orders of magnitude associated with each of these possibilities are derived from the work described in the description of the "other products . corrective factor" rule. It is assumed here that expenditure and income levels are strongly correlated.

divers.description:
In this category we have classified all the objects of our daily life, from the t-shirt to the washing machine,
but also the digital (from uses to devices).
divers.note:
Our model is clearly not comprehensive with respect to this item, so an underestimation of the footprint is likely.

So many everyday purchases (from bath mats to fire detectors to sunglasses...) are not yet included.

divers . √©lectrom√©nager.note: We're only counting the construction footprint of household appliances here, as their use mainly involves electricity, already counted via the kWh bill. So be careful not to confuse ADEME's LCA data (which take into account the entire life cycle: from cradle to grave) with the Base Carbone's EFs, which only give the impact of a product's manufacture (although they do include the "distribution" phase in the EF). These EFs do not consider the "use" and "end-of-life" phases, but they are the same data. NGC's use of these EFs is consistent, since electricity consumption linked to the product's "use" phase is taken into account by NGC via questions on consumption. The same applies to the "end-of-life" phase, which is taken into account via NGC's waste model (which takes into account the quantities of waste taken to waste collection centers, where household electrical appliances are (theoretically) taken at the end of their life). We assume that all household appliances are used by the whole household, even if some of them may only be used individually - a limitation of the test. Appliance lifespans evolve according to the preservation coefficient determined by the question on efforts to preserve equipment.

divers . √©lectrom√©nager . appareils.question: What appliances are less than 10 years old?
divers . √©lectrom√©nager . appareils.description:
The bulk of the appliance footprint lies in the appliances we buy.

> ‚ú®Ô∏è For simplicity's sake, only fill in recent appliances: a
> 10-year-old refrigerator has already been well amortized.

If not all your appliances are offered in this list, it's okay, this
test is not meant to be exhaustive.

divers . √©lectrom√©nager . pr√©servatio.question: What effort do you make to keep your appliances as long as possible?
divers . √©lectrom√©nager . pr√©servatio.description:
To avoid asking you to give the precise age of the ten or so appliances you own, we use a grid of the average age of each appliance.

For example, a fridge lasts an average of 10 years, an oven 12 years and a kettle 6 years.

> This is not the age of the appliance when it breaks down, but its age when the owner decides to replace it with a new one.

It's up to you to see where you stand in relation to the average.

divers . √©lectrom√©nager . coefficient.note:
We define a grid of consumer behaviors, from the almost compulsive new buyer to those who make a major effort to keep their appliances as long as possible.

We consider that the person who declares that he or she often buys new keeps his or her appliances for half of their average lifespan, while the person who keeps his or her appliances pushes back their average lifespan.

This grid may evolve if new sources or studies are added.

divers . loisirs.description: This category covers all cultural, sporting, leisure and wellness activities. In a first version of "Leisure", we first considered cultural and sporting practices.
divers . loisirs.note: The diversity of leisure activities is enormous. Here, we attempt an initial "macro" approach, i.e. we start with the total footprint of the sector in France, and bring it down to an individual level.

divers . loisirs . culture.question: What are your cultural practices?
divers . loisirs . culture.description: By "cultural practice" we mean going to the theater, ballet, opera or cinema, attending a street performance, playing an instrument or visiting a museum or park.

divers . loisirs . culture . empreinte t.note:
For the moment, we include concerts and shows, museums, publishing (press, books), and music practice.
TV subscriptions and gambling are excluded for the moment.

divers . loisirs . culture . empreinte p.description: A statistical calculation of cultural practices for the average French person.

somme: concerts et spectacles . moyenne macro fran√ßaise
mus√©es et monuments . moyenne macro fran√ßaise
pratique de la musique . moyenne macro fran√ßaise

divers . loisirs . culture . empreinte c.formule: concerts et spectacles . moyenne macro pond√©r√©e
divers . loisirs . culture . empreinte c.note: This category includes concerts, theaters, operas, ballets, street performances and cinemas.

divers . loisirs . culture . concerts et.question: Do you ever attend concerts or shows?

divers . loisirs . culture . concerts et.formule: empreinte branche . R90 par hab + empreinte branche . J59 par hab * 0.92
divers . loisirs . culture . concerts et.note: The French average is calculated by SDES (Service des Donn√©es et √âtudes Statistiques). It corresponds to the sum of fields corresponding to NAF codes R90 ("Creative, artistic and entertainment activities") and J59.1 ("Motion picture, video and television activities"). See details of this branch) This footprint is slightly overestimated, as film, video and television activities encompass a much wider swath of the economy than cinema alone. At present, we are unable to distinguish between the part of this sector corresponding to cinema, and that corresponding to television.

In 2022, French cinemas recorded 152 million admissions. In theater, 7.4 million tickets were sold in 2022. To this we can add 4.2 million admissions for live shows (2019 data). For street performances (same source), 37% attended a national event, 25% a local festival and 12% a mall event. Summing up these participations, we can estimate that half the population attended a street performance. Festivals recorded 7.4 million admissions in 2022. Lastly, in 2019, concerts recorded 27.9 million admissions. All these figures in relation to the size of the population lead us to believe that, on average, a French person attends 3 shows a year, all types of shows included (this is surely an underestimate, as it misses some of the shows for which tickets are not sold) The footprint attributed to the individual undergoes a rule of 3 in relation to this average attendance, which corresponds to the average footprint of the sector divided by the population.

divers . loisirs . culture . empreinte m.formule: mus√©es et monuments . moyenne macro pond√©r√©e
divers . loisirs . culture . empreinte m.note: This category includes visits to national museums and monuments, parks and zoos.

divers . loisirs . culture . mus√©es et.question: Do you ever visit museums, monuments and national parks?

divers . loisirs . culture . mus√©es et.formule: moyenne macro fran√ßaise * fr√©quence approxim√©e / proportion de visiteurs

divers . loisirs . culture . mus√©es et.note:
The French average has been calculated by SDES (Service des Donn√©es et √âtudes Statistiques). 
It corresponds to NAF code R91 ("Libraries, archives, museums and other cultural activities").

> This division includes the activities of libraries and archives, the management of museums of all kinds, botanical and zoological gardens, the management of historic sites and the activities of nature reserves. It also includes the preservation and exhibition of objects, sites and natural curiosities of historical, cultural and educational interest (World Heritage sites, etc.).

These factors have been set arbitrarily, via the study "Visiting museums, exhibitions and monuments in 2019", published by the French Ministry of Culture. According to this study, we have for museum and heritage visits : - 30% of the population are "amateurs": more than 3 visits a year - 37% of the population are "occasional" visitors: 1 to 2 visits a year - The rest are non-visitors These figures concern people over 18. There is therefore a slight bias here. Could we also reason per visit?
This question weights the footprint of museum visits according to the table described in the rule `museums and monuments . approximate frequency`.

divers . loisirs . culture . mus√©es et.titre: Three or more times a year

divers . loisirs . culture . mus√©es et.note: According to the study "Visiting museums, exhibitions and monuments in 2019", "69% of the population claim to have visited at least one monument, museum or exhibition". This figure is different from that found by summing up occasional and amateur visitors (which may exclude visitors to temporary exhibitions). What's more, it concerns people over the age of 18. So there's a slight bias here.

divers . loisirs . culture . empreinte √.note: This involves accounting for the carbon footprint associated with the purchase of books, newspapers and magazines.

divers . loisirs . culture . √©dition ..question: Do you ever buy books, magazines or newspapers?

divers . loisirs . culture . √©dition ..formule: empreinte branche . J58 par hab + empreinte branche . G47 par hab * 0.04 * (0.27 + 0.12)
divers . loisirs . culture . √©dition ..note: We include here the publishing branch (J58) as well as the share of book and newspaper publishing in branch G47 "Retail trade, except of motor vehicles and motorcycles per capita". See details of this branch)

On average, households spend ‚Ç¨1040 a year on cultural goods and services, of which 22% goes on books and the press, i.e. ‚Ç¨228, or just under ‚Ç¨20 a month. With an average household size of 2.2 people, we can estimate that an adult spends an average of just under ‚Ç¨10 a month on press, books and software.

divers . loisirs . culture . empreinte p.formule: pratique de la musique . moyenne macro pond√©r√©e
divers . loisirs . culture . empreinte p.note: This includes the practice of music, through the possession of one or more musical instruments.

divers . loisirs . culture . pratique de.question: Do you own a musical instrument?

divers . loisirs . culture . pratique de.formule: moyenne macro fran√ßaise / proportion de pratiquants

divers . loisirs . culture . pratique de.note:
At present, we consider the following branches:

- Manufacture of musical instruments (C32.2, corresponding to 2% of C32)
 
It could be interesting to integrate :

- Retail sale of musical instruments and sheet music (G47.00.58 but we don't have this level of detail: it belongs to the subcategory Retail sale of furniture, lighting equipment and other household articles in specialized stores, corresponding to 0.34 * 0.10 * G47)
- Music teaching (P85.52.12: currently fully included in public services)
- Musical instrument repair and maintenance services (S95.29.13: currently counted under "current expenditure / new products")

According to this study, 6% of French people play a musical instrument regularly. 31% have learned but no longer play or hardly play at all. This other study (unfortunately a little dated) leads us to believe that as long as people have learned music, they own a musical instrument at home (same proportion of learners and owners). We can therefore estimate that 37% of French people own a musical instrument at home.

divers . loisirs . sports.question: What sports do you practice regularly?
divers . loisirs . sports.note:
The notion of regularity is deliberately imprecise, as it depends on the sports practised and the level of the athlete. 

For example, sailing once a month might be considered regular, while jogging once a month might be considered anecdotal.

Also, a "committed" sportsman will consider regular practice to mean several training sessions a week, while a more amateur sportsman may set the bar a little lower.

divers . loisirs . sports . empreinte sp.note:
> There are so many questions that could be asked to estimate the footprint of sports-related leisure activities... 

To be exhaustive, we'd need to list all existing sports, ask about frequency of practice, facilities used, whether or not people belong to a club, and how often personal equipment is renewed.

But that would be far too many questions, given the weight of sport in the final footprint.

> For the moment, we estimate this footprint using a "macro" approach, i.e. we start with the footprint of the sector in France, which we then relate to the individual, weighting the values using "market" data: number of people practising, number of club members...

The macro subdivision we have at our disposal enables us to isolate: the use of sports facilities or general sports services (attributed to all sportsmen and women), sports club membership (attributed to all sportsmen and women whose sport is *majority* club-based), and fitness club membership (attributed to those who tick "gym or weight room").

In addition, a study carried out on behalf of the resorts of Tignes, Le Grand Bornand and La Clusaz has enabled us to allocate a footprint to winter sports enthusiasts.

divers . loisirs . sports . empreinte pa.note: Here we take the distribution of the total footprint of sports-related activities (63% of R93) over the French population. See details of this branch)

divers . loisirs . sports . balle ou bal.question: Do you play a racket sport?

divers . loisirs . sports . aquatique ..question: Do you practice any sports in the pool?

divers . loisirs . sports . martial ou c.question: Do you practice a martial or fighting art?

divers . loisirs . sports . salle de spo.question: Do you go to a gym, fitness center or bodybuilding studio?

divers . loisirs . sports . nautique . p.question: Do you practice any water sports?

divers . loisirs . sports . hiver montag.question: Do you practice a winter or mountain sport?

divers . loisirs . sports . sports √©ner.titre: Motorized sports or sports requiring motorized equipment

divers . loisirs . sports . sports √©ner.question: Do you practice a sport involving a motorized vehicle?

divers . loisirs . sports . autres sport.question: Do you practice a sport that is not listed?

divers . loisirs . sports . notif sports.description:
Some sports (motorized, water sports, etc.) are likely to have a significantly higher carbon footprint than others.
The current calculation method does not allow us to assess these differences, but the team is working on the subject!
divers . loisirs . sports . notif sports.note:
Please note that we are not including golf here, as a priori the environmental footprint of golf is mainly linked to water consumption.
We would nevertheless need to find the footprint linked to land use.

variations.alors: ((empreinte SDES sport par fran√ßais / proportion pratiquants) / proportion pratiquants adh√©rents) * 0.41

divers . loisirs . sports . empreinte cl.note: Here we take the share of sports club activities (41%) from economic branch R93, broken down according to the proportion of sportsmen and women who are members of a sports club. See details of this branch)

divers . loisirs . sports . proportion p.note: According to Les chiffres clef du sport 2020, in 2018, a third of sports enthusiasts were members of a club.

divers . loisirs . sports . empreinte fi.formule: (empreinte SDES sport par fran√ßais / proportion abonn√©s fitness) * 0.11
divers . loisirs . sports . empreinte fi.note: Here we take the share of fitness center activities (11%), broken down according to the proportion of sportsmen and women who subscribe to this type of center. See details of this branch)

divers . loisirs . sports . proportion a.note: According to Deloitte, in 2018, France had 5.96 million fitness club subscribers.

divers . loisirs . sports . empreinte r√.formule: (empreinte SDES sport par fran√ßais / proportion pratiquants) * ( 0.27 + 0.21 )
divers . loisirs . sports . empreinte r√.note: Here we take the share of Sports Facility Management (27%) and Other Sports-related Activities (21%) within Sports-related Activities (63%), multiplied by the proportion of registered sportsmen and women in France. See details of this branch)

divers . loisirs . sports . proportion p.note: According to Les chiffres clef du sport 2020, in 2018, 75% of individuals over the age of 15 said they had taken part in at least one utilitarian or recreational sporting activity during the year.

divers . loisirs . sports . empreinte mo.formule: empreinte jour montagne * nombre moyen jours montagne
divers . loisirs . sports . empreinte mo.note: We take the average time spent in winter sports for everyone who ticks the box.

divers . loisirs . sports . empreinte jo.note: Based on this study commissioned by Tignes, La Clusaz and Le Grand Bornand. We only take into account ski area maintenance (diesel-powered groomers) and infrastructure (ski lifts).

divers . loisirs . sports . nombre moyen.note: Based on Union Sports et Cycles figures, 53.8 million ski days are sold each year to 10 million skiers.

divers . loisirs . sports . empreinte SD.note: 63% corresponds to sales in the 'Sports-related activities' sub-branch of the 'Sports, leisure and recreation services' branch. See details of this branch)
divers . loisirs . sports . empreinte SD.titre: SDES sport footprint per French person

divers . num√©rique.description:
Digital has been at the heart of environmental news since 2019.

Yet its footprint isn't necessarily what we think it is: for example, the multiple devices in our homes are surprisingly large.

divers . num√©rique . internet.formule: empreinte horaire * dur√©e journali√®re * commun . jours par an

divers . num√©rique . internet . consomm.note: This figure is taken from a CarbonBrief article using IEA data, and criticizing the Shift Project's initial calculations of the carbon footprint of video streaming. > "Taken together, my updated analysis suggests that streaming a Netflix video in 2019 typically consumed around 0.077kWh of electricity per hour." Which considering the footprint of the global electricity mix for the year results in 36 gCO‚ÇÇ/hour of video streaming. We choose not to differentiate between modes of Internet use (and therefore the hourly electricity consumption associated with each of these uses) because the electricity consumption associated with video streaming is already low (it would be even lower for an hour of e-mailing or reading a newspaper article online). Combined with a low-carbon electricity mix (as is the case in France), this represents, in fine emissions. Note, however, that power consumption depends on the terminal used, and is therefore much higher on a 50-inch ultra HD TV than on a smartphone Here are other sources that give significantly different results: - 400 gCO‚ÇÇ/h for the Shift Project (after correction) - 100 gCO‚ÇÇ/h for Netflix (DIMPACT) - 36 gCO‚ÇÇ/h for the IEA (even reduced to 4g for France if I understand correctly, due to the carbon intensity of the electricity mix) - 28 gCO‚ÇÇ/h for Greenspector (for use of Canal + services)

divers . num√©rique . internet . dur√©e.question: How many hours a day do you spend on the Internet outside the office (sending e-mails, surfing the Web, streaming video, etc.)?
divers . num√©rique . internet . dur√©e.description: Just make a rough estimate of your personal hours of use (evenings, weekends), because what you do at work is included in your company's or organization's accounts.
divers . num√©rique . internet . dur√©e.note: According to M√©diam√©trie, the French spent an average of 2h18 on the Internet in 2022 ( source)

divers . num√©rique . pr√©servation.question: What effort do you make to keep your electronics as long as possible?
divers . num√©rique . pr√©servation.description:
To avoid asking you to give the precise age of all the electronic devices you own, we use an average age grid for each device, which is adjusted according to your efforts to preserve it or not
for each device, which is adjusted according to your efforts to preserve it or not.

It's up to you to judge your efforts to make them last as long as possible

> Answering "None, I often buy new" is the most impactful answer because it means that you are replacing your appliances early even before they are out of use.

divers . num√©rique . coefficient pr√©se.note:
We define a grid of consumer behaviors, from the almost compulsive new buyer to those who make a major effort to keep their appliances as long as possible.

We consider that the person who declares that he or she often buys new keeps his or her appliances for half of their average lifespan, while the person who keeps his or her appliances pushes back their average lifespan.

This grid may evolve if new sources or studies are added.

divers . num√©rique . appareils.question: What digital devices do you own that are less than 10 years old?
divers . num√©rique . appareils.description:
Some devices are shared in the household (TV, computer ...), others personal (telephone ...): it is taken into account in the calculation!

> ‚ú®Ô∏è For simplicity's sake, only include recent devices: a TV that is more than 10 years old has already been well amortized.

> We will soon improve the model to take into account reconditioned devices. 
> For the moment, we advise you to add them here even the benefit of this purchase compared to the new one will not be visible in the calculation.
divers . num√©rique . appareils.note:
This category is somewhat unusual in terms of depreciation. Unlike furnishings, where everything is considered to be shared within the household,
here, some appliances are shared, while others are considered individual.

We have therefore arbitrarily defined individual devices (telephone, tablet, camera)
and collective (TV, desktop computer, video projector, home cinema, Bluetooth speaker, voice speaker, home console).

divers . num√©rique . appareils . t√©l√©.note:
Phones, and especially recent smartphones, are the symbol par excellence of *high-tech*, which is known to consume a lot of resources.
The issue is all the more important as they are often renewed regularly, for example with each annual release of the new iPhone.
In reality, especially compared to the number of hours we spend on these small objects, their climate footprint could be compatible with a sustainable lifestyle. Illustration:
A high-end phone (iPhone X) is < 100kgCO2e. Assuming we buy this state-of-the-art smartphone every 2 years, we have < 50kgCO2e/year. This represents half a percent of the average footprint of a French person (11 tons). And 2.5% of a sustainable footprint of 2 tons/year.
If you don't have a cell phone, chances are you have a landline.

The lifetime is taken from this study [ADEME](https://librairie.ademe.fr/consommer-autrement/5226-evaluation-de-l-impact-environnemental-du-numerique-en-france-et-analyse-prospective.html), Report 2 Table 48 page 71

In the first version of Nos Gestes Climat we divided the possibilities of this question into three categories, according to the availability of data in the carbon base and manufacturers).

- Basic phone (also called "feature phone", which today are a cross between the famous Nokia 3310 and the smartphone, with a small screen and low-end components)
- Classic smartphone (mid-range, which accounts for the overwhelming majority of sales. Almost all smartphones sold in 2021 will have a screen larger than 5.5 inches)
- Top-of-the-range smartphone (the GES balance sheet database does not include "top-of-the-range phone" or "screen > 6 inches" categories. Moreover, the footprint of an iPhone 11 estimated by Apple itself is 72kg of CO‚ÇÇ, 79% of which so ~57kg just for production. 
  Unless the scope of the studies is not the same, but a larger scope taken by the company than by the environmental authority is astonishing to say the least, we retain the manufacturer's value.

Nevertheless, the latest NegaOctet data (see Empreinte database), like the manufacturers, seem to give a higher value than the Carbon database figures.

To simplify the questionnaire, allow several phones to be counted (several purchases in recent years), 
and in view of the fact that smartphones are the phones most frequently used, we have made the (more conservative) assumption 
that the footprint of a smartphone's construction is closer to that communicated by Apple in particular 
(see point above for the 57kg per unit figure).

See
  - https://www.bilans-ges.ademe.fr/fr/basecarbone/donnees-consulter/liste-element?recherche=Smartphone
  - https://www.bilans-ges.ademe.fr/fr/accueil/documentation-gene/index/page/produits_informatiques__electr
  - https://www.apple.com/environment/pdf/products/iphone/iPhone_11_PER_sept2019.pdf

divers . num√©rique . appareils . appare.note: We put the camera in the digital category because of the scarcity of silver cameras today.
divers . num√©rique . appareils . appare.question: Do you use a camera?

divers . num√©rique . appareils . appare.note:
The lifespan of the devices changes according to the preservation coefficient determined by the question on the efforts to preserve its devices.
An answer "average effort" does not change the life span. Only the other answers increase or decrease the lifespan of the appliances and therefore the estimated carbon footprint.

No information on the life span is available either in ADEME studies or on the web (where the life span of a camera is approximated in thousands of shots).
We therefore consider a lifespan of 5 years.

divers . num√©rique . appareils . home c.formule: empreinte * nombre / (dur√©e * coefficient pr√©servation * logement . habitants)

divers . num√©rique . appareils . home c.question: Do you use a home theater?

divers . num√©rique . appareils . home c.note: The lifetime is taken from this study [ADEME](https://librairie.ademe.fr/consommer-autrement/5226-evaluation-de-l-impact-environnemental-du-numerique-en-france-et-analyse-prospective.html), Report 2 Table 48 page 71

divers . num√©rique . appareils . ordina.question: Do you use a laptop computer?

divers . num√©rique . appareils . ordina.note: The lifetime is taken from this study [ADEME](https://librairie.ademe.fr/consommer-autrement/5226-evaluation-de-l-impact-environnemental-du-numerique-en-france-et-analyse-prospective.html), Report 2 Table 48 page 71

divers . num√©rique . appareils . ordina.formule: empreinte * nombre / (dur√©e * coefficient pr√©servation * logement . habitants)
divers . num√©rique . appareils . ordina.note:
We consider that a fixed computer is a tower and a detached screen (even if there are fixed computers where everything is "integrated" in the screen).
We consider the emission factor "Computer - fixed - high performance" of the Carbon Base

divers . produits consommables.formule: empreinte par mois * commun . mois par an
divers . produits consommables.description:
The aim here is to remove consumables, which are not amortized, from the "expenses" question,
in the same way as "long-term" purchases such as a musical instrument. 
The second challenge is to quantify the climate footprint of hygiene and cleaning products using a "consumption" approach
"emission factors already exist for these products.
On the other hand, the difficulty lies in the question put to the user: who is in a position to answer easily
about their consumption in terms of weight, volume or ‚Ç¨? The aim here is to facilitate the answer by defining different levels of consumption
based on quantity consumed (EFs are defined in kgCO2e/kg of product).

divers . produits consommables . emprein.titre: Footprint of consumables over a month
divers . produits consommables . emprein.note:
For this question, and in order to facilitate the answer, we decided to propose a predefined choice (arbitrarily) among 3 levels of answer,
considering that a product weighs around 500 grams.
  
  - Low consumption of 1 kg of products per month 
  - Normal consumption: 2 kg per month
  - High consumption: 5 kg per month

To help us define these levels, and on the basis of internet research,
we have assumed that a "normal" consumption of these products per person per year is:

For hygiene products:
  - perfumery (perfumes, eau de toilette, etc.): 500g
  - toiletries (soaps, shower gels, deodorants, toothpastes, etc.): 3kg
  - hair care products (shampoos, hairsprays, gels, styling mousse, hair color, etc.): 3kg
  - cosmetics (make-up, skincare creams, baby products, sun creams, etc.): 2kg

For cleaning products :
  - Dishwashing liquid: 2kg
  - Dishwashing detergent: 3kg (3 washes per week, 20g per wash)
  - Liquid detergent: 5kg (2 washes per week, 50g per wash)
  - Multi-purpose cleaner: 5kg

A "normal amount" consumed by one person is thus estimated at 2kg per month.

divers . produits consommables . consomm.question: How would you estimate your monthly consumption of hygiene products (soap, make-up...) and cleaning products (laundry, household products...)?
divers . produits consommables . consomm.description:
This question enables us to evaluate *simply* the climate footprint of your consumption of personal care products 
(perfumes, shower gels, shampoos, deodorants, toothpastes, make-up, skincare creams, sun creams...) and cleaning products 
(laundry detergents, dishwasher detergents, household products, etc.) based on 3 consumption levels.

divers . tabac.description: Tobacco is responsible for a major impact on the climate. But of course, that's not the only problem it's responsible for! According to WHO: > "Every year, the tobacco industry is responsible for more than 8 million deaths, the destruction of 600 million trees, 200,000 hectares of land, the loss of 22 billion tons of water and the emission of 84 million tons of CO2."

divers . empreinte cigarette.description: This figure is taken from the article Cigarette Smoking: An Assessment of Tobacco's Global Environmental Footprint Across Its Entire Supply Chain. The scope of the study takes into account the entire life cycle, from the farming phase to smoke emissions. Most of the impact lies in the farming, drying and manufacturing phases.

divers . tabac . consommation.formule: consommation par semaine * nombre de cigarettes par paquet * commun . semaines par an

divers . tabac . consommation par semain.question: How much do you smoke each week?
divers . tabac . consommation par semain.description:
üí° Enter your weekly cigarette consumption here. A pack is considered to contain 20 cigarettes.
If you smoke rolls, remember to adapt your calculation.

Note that the impact of tobacco isn't just carbon: it's also responsible for deforestation, and the significant use of water and farmland!

> For the moment, we're only considering conventional cigarettes.
> Electronic cigarettes are not yet included in our calculations, due to lack of data!
divers . tabac . consommation par semain.note: According to the INSEE study on household spending in 2017, a household spends an average of ‚Ç¨402 a year on tobacco (all households combined). The price of a pack of cigarettes in 2017 was ‚Ç¨7.05 on average. For a household of 2.2 people (the French average), and at 20 cigarettes per pack, the average French person therefore consumes around 520 cigarettes a year, or 26 packs a year, or half a pack a week! > Another source of data: according to Sant√© Publique France, a smoker consumes an average of 12.7 cigarettes a day, or 4636 cigarettes a day, equivalent to 65 kgCO2e a year. However, this figure is not included in the calculation. On the basis of the assumptions set out at the beginning of this paragraph, each French person consumes an average of around 7 kgCO2e.

divers . tabac . nombre de cigarettes pa.note:
It is assumed that a pack contains 20 cigarettes.
This assumption may be misleading for people who consume rolled cigarettes.

divers . textile.question: What new clothes do you usually buy in a year?
divers . textile.description:
Tell us what you put in your shopping bags this year, or in a
representative year if you rarely go shopping.

> If you buy a sweater every 2 years, round to `1`. If you buy a sweater
> every 3 years, round to `0`.

Enter only new products. We voluntarily exclude items bought in thrift stores, recovered from friends and family, and second hand in general.
divers . textile.note: The data are all taken from Base Carbone except for the shorts, which come from Base Impact data (textiles, household linen, leather goods) and the two generic items, which are rough estimates based on visualization of the ADEME documentation data graph (Scope 3 / Textile / Cotton, synthetic, other). We have not used Base Impact data (except in the case of shorts), because even if the data corresponds to the average of several products, many of them come from just one company. It should be noted that the default values appear to be underestimated, given these statistics on French purchasing habits.

divers . textile . notif d√©barras surpl.description:
> Did you know? 

> According to a study commissioned by moving company Movinga in 2018, the French don't wear 68% (!) of their wardrobe. That's more than two-thirds of the contents of our wardrobes that never get out.

> Before buying a new item: what if you did a bit of sorting?

empreinte SDES.titre: Carbon footprint per French person estimated by the SDES
empreinte SDES.description:
The calculation of the French individual carbon footprint proposed here is based on the work of the SDES for the year **2017** 
GHG emissions are estimated from each euro of final demand for each of the major product categories (goods and services) identified by the national accounts.

The carbon footprint calculated here is therefore composed of direct household emissions (from fuels consumed by individual vehicles and fossil fuels used in the home), and of direct emissions from the transportation of goods 
and fossil fuels used in household boilers) and the emissions associated with the goods and services 
and the emissions associated with the goods and services supplied to the final demand. The origin of the emissions of these goods and services is identified and allows to
emissions from domestic production and those associated with imports. Imports can be addressed to
to final demand or consumed by economic activities (raw materials, semi-finished products).

population.note:
French population in 2017 (to remain consistent with the figures of the national footprint estimate)
A question arises as to whether or not to include the DOM/TOM. We propose to include them.
Source SDES for this question: "Kyoto perimeter", i.e. metropolitan France and overseas territories belonging to the EU".
The source is therefore: https://www.insee.fr/en/statistiques/serie/001760077.

√©missions direct m√©nages par hab.description: Corresponds to direct household emissions (from fuels consumed by individual vehicles and fossil fuels used in housing boilers)

√©missions direct m√©nages france.description: Corresponds to direct household emissions (from fuels consumed by individual vehicles and fossil fuels used in housing boilers)
√©missions direct m√©nages france.note: Figure taken from the French Ministry of Ecology's estimate of France's national footprint

√©missions hors direct m√©nages par hab.description: Corresponds to the emissions associated with goods and services addressed to the final demand

empreinte branche . C21 par hab . servic.description: A large part of the pharmaceutical products are drugs that are available to us or available to citizens in hospital departments. On the other hand, some pharmaceutical products are distributed without prescription and are now commercial products (e.g. a food supplement). In a first approach, we have taken into account in public services only the share (in turnover) of reimbursable products. (90% in 2017, see Table 1) We finally revised this distribution by considering 100% of this branch in view of the indispensable nature of medicines, medical equipment, vaccines etc... at our disposal. It is also envisaged to work on the reimbursable share of each type of product (higher for essential products) and thus allocate part of this item in market services.
empreinte branche . C21 par hab . servic.formule: C21 par hab * ratio services publics

empreinte branche . C30 par hab . servic.description:
This division covers the construction of transport vehicles (excluding automobiles) for freight (sea, rail, air) 
or passenger transport (bus, metro, ferry, commercial aircraft).

The field concerns civil, military or recreational equipment.

It is a common market service because public transport is a service accessible to all citizens and freight
accessible to all citizens and freight enables us to transport all the products we consume.

We do not include 100% of this item to avoid double counting. Indeed, the construction of trains, buses, streetcars, airplanes etc...
is already taken into account in the emission factors used to calculate your travel footprint in the Transport section.

We therefore consider here the construction of ships and floating structures (30.11), 50% of the sub-division aeronautical and space construction (30.3, helicopters), and the construction of ships (30.4)
(30.3, helicopters, canadair), military combat vehicles (30.4, breakdown not known because turnover subject to statistical secrecy), 
cycles and vehicles for the disabled (30.92) and other transport vehicles (30.99, sledges, carts, carts), 
all of which contribute to 50% of the turnover of this branch.

empreinte branche . E36 par hab . servic.description: The water distribution system is a public service, although it is often operated by private companies, at the discretion of the municipality. Everyone has easy access to running water in France. It would be possible in a future version to modulate the individual footprint according to water consumption, as is done for electricity and other energy sources, but let's keep in mind that this item, along with the climate indicator, is very low.

empreinte branche . E37 par hab . servic.description: The wastewater treatment system is an essential public service for the health of citizens and the health of our waterways. It is one of the fundamental works of the networks underlying any French city. > The challenge is to reduce water pollution through preventive and curative approaches. Wastewater discharges directly into nature pollute the soil and rivers, but also the water tables from which a large part of the drinking water comes. The proportion of households not connected to a wastewater treatment system varies widely between 0 (dense departments) and 35% (Indre). We do not have an estimate of the carbon footprint of households without sewage treatment, but it should obviously not be zero.
empreinte branche . E37 par hab . servic.formule: E37 par hab * ratio services publics

empreinte branche . F43 par hab . servic.description: This division includes specialized construction activities (special works), i.e. the construction of parts of buildings and civil engineering works or the preparation for this purpose. These are usually specialized activities involving a common aspect of different structures, requiring special skills or equipment, such as pile driving, foundation work, structural work, concreting, masonry, paving, scaffolding, roofing, etc. Completion and finishing work is also covered. From what we understand from the documentation associated with the emissions factor we use for housing construction in the Nos Gestes Climat model, it appears that emissions related to the construction site are not included. > The values indicated correspond to the only contributor "products and equipment" implemented during the construction of a building (the other contributors to environmental impacts and in particular to climate change are, for a building: the construction site, water consumption, energy consumption related to real estate and furniture; but, with the exception of the construction site, the impacts related to these contributors will take place throughout the life of the building). We therefore include in utilities several sub-divisions of this branch: - Demolition and site preparation (43.1) - Other specialized construction (43.99) In addition, since we do not have data to differentiate what falls under work for public infrastructure, we have considered for the moment a ratio of 1/3 for the rest of the subdivisions of this branch. The ratio thus calculated from the branch turnover is therefore equivalent to 54%. If you have more information, do not hesitate to contribute.
empreinte branche . F43 par hab . servic.formule: F43 par hab * ratio services publics
empreinte branche . F43 par hab . servic.titre: 54% Miscellaneous works (for public works and buildings)

empreinte branche . M71 par hab . servic.description:
Architecture and engineering activities; technical control and analysis activities.

Includes the provision of architectural, engineering, drafting, building inspection, surveying and mapping services. It also includes the provision of physical, chemical and other analytical services.

This division concerns both public and private infrastructures, but we consider it a public service because it allows us to generally manage the safety of the building and therefore of each citizen entering a building.

empreinte branche . M72 par hab . servic.description:
Whether it is for R&D, natural and engineering sciences or social sciences and humanities 
we consider that research activities are common public services: every citizen benefits from the advances 
from the advances linked to public and private research.

 Moreover, we have noticed that the budgets of public research centers
(CNRS, INRA, Inserm, IRD, CEA...) cover the majority of the turnover of this division.

logement . chauffage.question: What type of energy do you use for heating, hot water, cooking, etc.?
logement . chauffage.description:
> This question covers all the energy sources you use to power your heaters, water heaters, hobs, etc.

Some homes use electricity only, others are heated entirely by gas, and more rarely by wood or oil.
In still other situations, a home may be heated mainly by electric heaters or a heat pump,
but with wood as a back-up, for example. Finally, you can also take into account your gas consumption for your van or motor home. 

Tick all the modes you use.

logement . chauffage . gaz . biogaz.question: Have you subscribed to a gas contract that includes biogas (or biomethane)?
logement . chauffage . gaz . biogaz.description:
Biogas, or biomethane, is a gas produced from organic waste (household waste, manure, lawn waste, crops, etc.), unlike fossil gas, misleadingly called "natural" gas, which is extracted like oil from the Norwegian or Russian subsoil.

For some years now, it has been possible to subscribe to a contract that guarantees the injection into the French gas network of the same quantity of biomethane as your own consumption. The gas you consume in your home will in any case be a mixture mainly made up of the methane molecule (CH‚ÇÑ), but for every kWh of gas consumed, 1 kWh of biomethane will have been injected "on your behalf".

> Unlike gas, electricity *can't be stored*, which is why we don't offer a "green electricity" option in the simulator.

Please note that there are offers with only 10% or 20% biomethane. If this is the case, answer "no".

logement . chauffage . gaz . avertisseme.description:
You will find that choosing biogas greatly reduces the climate footprint
of the gas you consume, but note that current production is unable to
scale up: the overall reduction of all gas consumption remains
essential, whether you consume biogas or fossil gas.

logement . chauffage . gaz . facteur d'√.note:
These are kgCO2e/kWh *PCS*.

We reason in HCV (Higher Calorific Value) and not in LCV (Lower Calorific Value), as HCV is used as a conversion coefficient in invoices to convert the volume of gas used into kWh: 
it is assumed that the gas boiler recovers the latent heat of condensation.

Base Carbone Natural gas - 2022/average mix/consumption

logement . chauffage . biogaz.note:
The carbon base uses the following biogas emission factor: `0.0444 kgCO2e/kWhPCI`. Here is more documentation on the integration of this figure and its limitations.
Their justification is in the documentation [unfold] For methodological reasons, this approach is not compatible with the Base Carbone¬Æ emissions factor construction logic, and cannot be used to produce a GHG emissions balance. Accordingly, further work was carried out, resulting in an updated LCA for 2020 [144 ] and an emissions factor of 44.1 gCO2e / kWh ICP. This latter value reflects the GHG impact induced by the production of one kWh of biomethane, in contrast to the value of 23.4 gCO2e / kWh PCI from the previous study, which reflects the overall impact of the methanization and injection sector, integrating induced impacts and reductions in GHG emissions brought about by this sector.

We'll need to clarify what in NGC prevents us from using the lowest factor in this consumption calculation model, which is a global calculation also covering agriculture via food. Another crucial point is that gas can be stored, unlike "green" electricity, which is why their emission factor has not yet been included in NGC. In addition, leaks from biomethane installations, which are by nature much smaller and more numerous than fossil gas and therefore difficult to control, could be underestimated. Is this study (202200267-6) taken into account in the above emissions factor (2020)? ## About land use The carbon base link to the GRDF study is no longer online. Here it is in PDF. It shows : ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1177762/189527416-4e8a3725-ef5a-448e-8557-0ad0007e0720.png) The red part is detailed here: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1177762/189527431-3fdcc5b2-22c0-49e1-b5f0-68762f780d57.png) It shows that the proportion of dedicated crops is very low, which is very reassuring. Having said that, and I'm not sure how to define it precisely, I still have a strong impression that a large proportion of these components could be valorized differently: in concrete terms, we burn and thus valorize at a very high price (gas at wholesale price costs in September 2022 almost 2 times the biogas production price (90‚Ç¨/MWh)) chicken leftovers from the canteen that we could just not have produced (blue); the domestic lawn that the neighbor mows every week (light blue); manure from crops that could have been dedicated to human vegetation (mauve); and so on. In short, if some of the energy present in the materials used by biomethane was just lost, another part simply undergoes a change of allocation, from something useful to the agricultural world to the combustion of gas to heat homes in particular. Not to mention the windfall effect for activities that emit, substitutable by others that emit less. The study seems to be very complete, so it's worth looking into. Maybe it answers all the questions I haven't seen (it's complex). There's also an article in Reporterre that worries about bacterial contamination due to digestate spreading, as well as methane and nitrous oxide N2O leaks, which are underestimated (because they are present and therefore evaluated in the study cited by the carbon base). Please note, however, that Reporterre is not a research organization, but an opinion medium. A very recent investigation into methanizers in Brittany points in the same direction, cataloguing the incidents that have taken place in the region: https://basta.media/des-methaniseurs-menacent-l-environnement-la-carte-inedite-des-accidents-en-Bretagne-Splann. In my opinion, this does not call into question the inclusion of this factor in UCS. Fossil gas production is also affected by this kind of problem, by way of example. Another question that may be answered here is: can the sector achieve x10 production without introducing negative externalities that are currently under control? It would be interesting to answer this question for the UCS user, to show him that his choice can be passed on to society as a whole. Carbone4 seems to answer in the negative: replacing fossil gas with biomethane should not lead to a failure to reduce gas consumption in general, and even less to a rebound effect! ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1177762/189527887-931ee20a-8ad6-431f-bd4d-d705fa9eefca.png) A **warning** is therefore integrated into the simulation to evoke this impossible transition to scale: > Biomethane reduces **enormously** the CO‚ÇÇ emissions of the gas you consume, but current production is **unable to scale up**: the overall reduction of all gas consumption remains **essential**, whether you consume biogas or fossil gas.

logement . chauffage . biogaz . part.question: How much biogas is guaranteed by your gas contract?
logement . chauffage . biogaz . part.description:
There are few gas vendors offering 100% biogas contracts, but there are some (as of September 2022). 

On the other hand, France's leading gas seller offers its customers a biogas option with an adjustable proportion at an additional cost (significant, but which doesn't double the bill either). Don't hesitate to talk to one of our advisors.

logement . chauffage . bouteille gaz . c.question: What is your annual consumption of gas bottles (13 kg)?
logement . chauffage . bouteille gaz . c.par d√©faut: parc fran√ßais . chauffage . consommation moyenne gaz cuisson / √©nergie par bouteille
logement . chauffage . bouteille gaz . c.description:
To simplify the answer to this question, we suggest you directly enter the number of gas cylinders you consume.
Here we're considering a 13kg capacity, the most widespread model and generally used for cooking gas.

If you wish to answer in kilograms, because the size of the bottle doesn't correspond to your needs, don't hesitate to use the conversion help.
logement . chauffage . bouteille gaz . c.note: There are no emission factors directly associated with gas cylinders, but it should be noted that they contain mainly propane and butane, gases for which emission factors are available. There are various types of cylinder, as shown in the infographic below, taken from the lepropane.com website. infographic of gas bottle models taken from the "lepropane.com" website](https://lepropane.com/sites/lepropane.com/files/images/infographies/dimensions-bouteilles.png) The most common cylinder is the 13kg model, generally used for cooking gas. For the purposes of this question, we'll consider a 13kg cylinder. As the cylinders themselves are returnable, we are only considering emissions linked to the gas itself.

logement . chauffage . bouteille gaz . e.question: You use a different size of cylinder? Enter your annual consumption in kg.
logement . chauffage . bouteille gaz . e.note:
This aid simplifies the conversion of kg of gas consumed into 13kg gas cylinders.

This estimation help mechanism is designed to receive monthly consumption as input (see InputEstimation.tsx on the site side).
However, in this particular case, we'd like to offer an estimation aid for the whole year, and expect consumption to be per year 
and not by month (a period that corresponds more closely to supplier invoices).
For this reason, the formula includes a factor of 12.
Average between butane and propane, whose emission factors are nevertheless very close.

logement . chauffage . bois . type . gra.par d√©faut: parc fran√ßais . chauffage . consommation bois par m2 * surface
logement . chauffage . bois . type . gra.description: > üí° Tip: on average, 1kg of pellets produce 4.6 kWh. So you can multiply your annual consumption (in tons) by 4600 kWh.
logement . chauffage . bois . type . gra.note: The default value here is a priori largely overestimated. Indeed, the data used CEREN) reflect poorly the reality of wood energy. The data on wood consumption of households aggregates both data on pellets (efficient in terms of combustion) and on wood logs in open fireplaces (poor performance). And so it is likely that if the discrimination by type of firewood was made in the CEREN data (for kWh consumed and surface heated) we would end up with a much lower value in kWh/m2 for pellets than for wood logs.

logement . chauffage . bois . facteur d'.note:
Please note: in the absence of a "generic validated" emission factor for wood logs in the Base Carbone, we have opted for a "specific validated" emission factor (E+/C- initiative = Positive Energy and Carbon Reduction label) 
(E+/C- initiative = Positive Energy and Carbon Reduction label), in order to ensure a degree of consistency for the user browsing the calculation model.
However, E+/C- emission factors are sometimes developed according to rules that differ from those used in the Base Carbone calculation.
It is therefore likely that this emission factor slightly underestimates the GHG impact of consuming one kWh of wood logs by not taking unburnt methane emissions into account.

Please note: in the absence of a "generic validated" emission factor for pellets in the Base Carbone (the generic validated EF available does not correspond to use in an individual stove but in a heating network), 
we have opted for a "specific validated" emission factor (E+/C- initiative = Positive Energy and Carbon Reduction label), in order to ensure a degree of consistency for the user browsing the calculation model.
However, E+/C- emission factors are sometimes developed according to rules that differ from those used in the Base Carbone calculation.
It is therefore likely that this emission factor slightly underestimates the GHG impact of consuming one kWh of wood logs by not taking unburnt methane emissions into account.

logement . chauffage . r√©seau de chaleu.titre: Footprint of gas consumption via heating network

logement . chauffage . r√©seau de chaleu.question: Is your home heated by a heating network?
No invoice? Enter your approximate monthly expenses
logement . chauffage . r√©seau de chaleu.note: This formula allows us to switch from ‚Ç¨/month to kWh/year: kWh costs x cents per month over 12 months. This figure is taken from theHeating and Cooling Network Survey based on 2021 data, which gives a figure of 80‚Ç¨HT/MWh. The heat and cooling sales price survey for 2019 gave a figure of 74.6‚Ç¨HT/MWh and 79.3‚Ç¨TTC/MWh, with a median of 82.3‚Ç¨TTC/MWh. As a first approximation, we have therefore chosen to base ourselves on the 2021 average, keeping the 2019 ratio and converting it to VAT, which gives a value of 85‚Ç¨TTC/MWh (this is not just a 5.5% or 20% rate, as the application of these rates varies according to the proportion of green energy in the heating network mix, vAT at 5.5% is applied to networks containing more than 50% renewable and recovered energy). This is an average value with a relatively large standard deviation. Nevertheless, the survey states that "average sales prices for heating networks vary widely, with 89% of heat delivered sold at a price between -30% and +30% of the national average".

parc fran√ßais.description:
The objective of this small model is to estimate the average values associated with the dwelling (surface, surface heated with gas, consumption by heating...) to obtain a total average footprint of the dwelling which is representative of the average French person

The difficulty is that some households heat with gas (~40%), electricity (~40%), oil, wood, etc

We therefore attribute as an average climate footprint the kWh footprint of these energies weighted by their actual use in the French housing stock.
parc fran√ßais.note: This model is based on the Ceren and SDES dataset Energy consumption by residential use.

logement . climatisation.description:
Here we estimate the footprint of air conditioning. 
Its footprint is fourfold:   
- electricity consumption (included in housing consumption)
- the footprint of equipment construction
- the footprint of heat transfer fluid leaks
  - annual
  - end-of-life
logement . climatisation.note:
There is a certain difference with the ADEME study, as the assumptions are different from those of the Base Empreinte, whereas the latter claims to be based on this study.

The main differences stem from

- the annual leakage rate considered: 1% in the ADEME study (tab p38), whereas our model averages the annual leakage rates for the residential sector given in the Base Empreinte (i.e. 4.2%)
- the fact that the ADEME study does not seem to take into account the end-of-life leakage rate (even if depreciated), which is enormous in the Base Empreinte (average of 66.4%)
- the fact that, in our first estimate, we consider R410a refrigerant, whereas the study considers R134a

logement . climatisation . pr√©sent.question: Do you use an air conditioning system to cool your home (electric air conditioner, heat pump)?
logement . climatisation . pr√©sent.description:
The air conditioner uses electricity, which you have to enter in kWh or ‚Ç¨ in the electricity question. The footprint of the electricity consumed by the air conditioner is therefore already calculated

But on top of that, an air conditioner emits other greenhouse gases: hence the need to ask this question.

logement . climatisation . rappel kWh.description: Do you have an air conditioner? Its electricity consumption will simply be included in the electricity bill, like all electrical appliances in the home. Refrigerant gas leaks are taken into account here.

logement . climatisation . nombre par d√.note: Source for the default figure: La climatisation de confort dans les b√¢timents r√©sidentiels et tertiaires, √©tat des lieux 2020, June 2021, page 3. > The survey of 800 households carried out by CODA Strat√©gies in the summer of 2020 as part of this study found an equipment rate of 25%, consistent with the data collected by EDF a year earlier. > This average rate of 25% masks major disparities. For example, 31% of owners of detached houses have air conditioning, compared with just 20% of households living in collective housing.

logement . climatisation . nombre.question: How many electric air conditioners do you have?

logement . climatisation . fuite annuell.formule: charge moyenne * taux de fuite annuel

logement . climatisation . charge moyenn.note: average of the average loads of the given residential table [here](https://bilans-ges.ademe.fr/fr/accueil/documentation-gene/index/page/Refrigeration_et_climatisation)

logement . climatisation . fuite annuell.note: average annual leakage rate for the residential panel shown here

logement . climatisation . fluide frigo.note:
The fluid considered is R410a and its emission factor from the Base Carbone.

Note found in the study [Modelling and environmental assessment of consumer products and capital goods](https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/127-modelisation-et-evaluation-environnementale-de-produits-de-consommation-et-biens-d-equipement.html):

> The refrigerant is the main contributor to the life cycle of air conditioners. Depending on the fluid used, the impacts can be very different, in fact, today we see new technologies using pentane, a gas with low global warming power compared to R134a.

We can consider a weighted average according to the proportions of each refrigerant used.

charge moyenne * taux de fuite fin de vie

Supposed to represent the impact of building an air conditioner but I'm taking the FE "mobile air conditioner" back

variations.alors: surface * annuelle et par surface / habitants

logement . construction.note:
The average home will last at least 50 years. This is a conservative value.

We consider here that the footprint of the construction of a dwelling is attributed every 50 years to the inhabitants of the first 50 years.

Thereafter, the construction footprint is set to zero.

Possible improvement: we lack data, but it should be possible to allocate an annual footprint for housing maintenance (restoration, insulation, interior work, etc.).

logement . construction . par surface.note: We decided to delete the question relating to the eco-construction of housing, as the associated carbon footprint was open to debate. As soon as we find reliable data, we'll put it back online!

Emission factor taken from the Empreinte database.

logement . construction . dur√©e d'amort.note: The lifespan of a building is set at 50 years (see empreinte documentation, Asset Purchases/Buildings tab).

logement . √©lectricit√© . consommation.note: we consider that only the electricity consumption related to heating is dependent on the surface of the dwelling
logement . √©lectricit√© . consommation.description:
Tip: You can find your annual electricity consumption on your bills or in your online account on your supplier's website.

As a reminder, if you live in several homes (for example, if you have a second home), try to "bring" these consumptions into those of the main home in order to have the most accurate estimate possible.

logement . √©lectricit√© . estimation vi.question: No invoice? Enter your approximate monthly expenses
logement . √©lectricit√© . estimation vi.note: This formula enables us to switch from ‚Ç¨/month to kWh/year. The figure includes a subscription cost, and therefore represents an average. It is not the marginal price per kWh. It includes taxes. Figure taken from Eurostat, household, second half 2021.

logement . √©lectricit√© . intensit√© ca.description:
Here we use the average footprint of the mix in the simulation region.

We could do better, by separating the air heating part from the rest of
the housing consumption, because heating is mainly used in winter, when
coal and gas plants are running more and worsening the mix footprint.
But this would require electrically heated households to find and report
both values, which is not easy to do.

> The intensity of residential heating is thus defined at 80gCO2e/kWh in
> France by the RE2020,
> [source](https://www.batiactu.com/edito/facteur-energie-primaire-contenu-carbone-electricite-58485.php).

heures moyennes par semaine * nombre semaines par an

logement . ext√©rieur . tondeuse thermiq.note: On average, we can assume that French people with a garden spend 1 hour mowing their lawn ( source)
We are basing ourselves on the ADEME's hypotheses, i.e. that the French mow their lawns every three weeks for around 6 months. That's around 9 times a year.

The petrol used in a lawnmower is generally E5 or E10.
We use the emission factor from the Empreinte database. 
To maintain independence between models, we do not call up the variable associated with the car here.

In addition, [this source[(http://www.bva-xsight.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/Weber_Les-Francais-et-le-barbecue_Infographie-2023.pdf)] gives us a breakdown of the types of barbecue owned. logement . ext√©rieur . empreinte barbec.note:
Unlike electric and gas barbecues, charcoal barbecues have a significant usage footprint: burning charcoal to cook food emits a significant amount of greenhouse gases. 
So we're counting both the construction and usage footprints.

logement . ext√©rieur . empreinte usage.note: This data is taken from the work of Boris Proulx, Sandrine Vieira, C√©dric Gagnon and Antoine Noreau for Le Devoir source)

logement . ext√©rieur . nombre moyen bar.note: According to this Statista study, we can estimate that the average number of barbecues per year per French person is 17 (weighted average across population groups).
logement . ext√©rieur . nombre moyen bar.titre: average number of barbecues per year

logement . ext√©rieur . empreinte constr.formule: poids moyen barbecue charbon * facteur acier
logement . ext√©rieur . empreinte constr.note:
It was not possible to find the construction footprint of a charcoal barbecue. We found that most of them were made of steel, so we've given them the footprint of their weight in steel.
As the weight varies widely, we decided to use the weight of a 'classic' Weber barbecue with a diameter of 57 cm, i.e. 12 kg.

logement . ext√©rieur . facteur acier.note: Emission factor from the Empreinte database (steel or tinplate/new)

logement . ext√©rieur . part propri√©tai.note: According to this source, 85% of French people with a garden have a barbecue. In addition, [this source[(http://www.bva-xsight.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/Weber_Les-Francais-et-le-barbecue_Infographie-2023.pdf)] gives us a breakdown of the types of barbecue owned. This includes charcoal barbecues.

logement.description:
We can see our housing as a passive building that would not impact the
climate... we would be wrong!

The most important emission item for housing in France is heating the
air in which we live. The footprint will not be the same at all
depending on the heating technology.

But that's not all: construction, maintenance, hot water heating,
electricity, so many items that depend above all on a single parameter:
the number of m¬≤.

logement . saisie habitants.question: How many people live in your home?
logement . saisie habitants.description:
We need to know how many people share your home and all the
consumption it entails (construction, heating, etc.).

> If you live alone, answer `1`.

> If you live with your spouse and a child, answer `3`.

> If you are separated with a child who alternates between your home and
> another, you can enter `1.5`.

logement . notif minimum habitants.description:
The number of inhabitants cannot be zero or less than 1. You are the first inhabitant of your dwelling.

As the footprint of the home and other items such as household appliances are divided by the number of inhabitants, it must be greater than 1.

So we don't take into account empty homes you own, or rented accommodation in which neither you nor anyone else lives.

logement . surface.question: What is the surface area of your home?
logement . surface.note: Default value obtained in this Ceren and SDES dataset. > Dwellings have an average surface area of around 91 m2. > If you live in an unusual dwelling, such as a camper van / truck / barge, simply enter the m¬≤ of this dwelling.

logement . notif minimum surface.description: The area of your home cannot be zero.

logement . appartement.question: Is your home a flat?
logement . appartement.description:
As opposed to a single-family home.

The increase in apartment housing can make us forget that the house remains the majority dwelling for French households in 2018.

This information influences not only the construction footprint, but also the possibilities for insulation work, for example.

> If you live in an unusual type of dwelling, such as a camper van / truck / barge, no problem: choose "apartment" and enter the m¬≤ of what constitutes your dwelling.
logement . appartement.note: In 2018, single-family homes accounted for 56% of all housing units ( Source: INSEE): the majority of both primary residences and secondary and occasional homes. After increasing between 1999 and 2008, its share is declining slightly, as the number of multi-family dwellings is increasing faster than that of single-family dwellings due to recent trends in new construction. It should be noted that this is a proportion of dwellings; however, it can be expected (to be verified) that houses contain more people on average than apartments, which reinforces the choice of the default value.

logement . √¢ge.question: How old is your home?
logement . √¢ge.note: In France, 24% of the housing stock dates from before 1949 and 24% from between 1949 and 1974, according to INSEE. For Paris, this interactive map is fascinating if you're interested in the age of its housing stock.

logement . notif amortissement.description:

We also ignore the transport of purchased chlorine, which in practice is often by car, implying a non-negligible consumption of gasoline, but of second order a priori.

logement . piscine . masse de chlore.description: > ‚ÑπÔ∏è This rule comes from the `futureco-data` model. > If you opt for a chlorine treatment, you will need to count on an annual budget of approximately ‚Ç¨150 for chlorine, ‚Ç¨20 for flocculant, ‚Ç¨30 for an anti-scale product and ‚Ç¨30 for a product to rebalance the pH, which corresponds to an annual budget of approximately ‚Ç¨230 On the basis of the hypotheses sourced in the references below, for the time being and in order to obtain an initial order of magnitude, we equate all the chemicals used in a swimming pool with chlorine. We then use an order of magnitude for the price of chlorine: on April 20, 2021, prices of ‚Ç¨35/5kg of pool chlorine. On the basis of ‚Ç¨150 worth of chlorine per year, this gives ~4 kg, which is consistent with the 5 kg package size. We also don't know how the chlorine purchased is transported, often by car. The result calculated here has an order of magnitude consistent with that given in this article, ~ 20 kg.
